newsitem.title: USA: Calif lawmakers close to utility deregulation plan.
newsitem.headline: Calif lawmakers close to utility deregulation plan.

text.p: A California legislative committee moved closer on Friday to finalizing a plan to help investor-owned utilities write-off "stranded" costs to better compete in a deregulated California market.
The joint Assembly-Senate conference committee was now expected to finalize its proposed legislation by Monday, state officials working with the committee said on Friday.
"This proposal is very nearly done," said David Takashima, chief of staff to state Senator Steve Peace, conference committee chairman.

"We believe that by the close of this month, both the state Senate and Assembly would approve it. We also have indications the Governor would be supportive of signing this legislation," Takashima added.

Lawmakers on the committee have agreed that as of January 1998, electric utility customers in the state would have a choice of providers. Under the proposal, however, municipal utilities would not be required to open their markets.
To help investor-owned utilities in the state write-off their stranded costs, the state would enact a statewide competitive transition charge, Takashima said.
The amount of the charge would be set by the California Public Utilities Commission. The charge would be collected through the year 2001, Takashima said.
While this charge was in place, investor-owned utility rates in the state would be frozen, he added.
The competitive transition charge could be used by the utilities to directly write-off stranded costs such as nuclear power facilities and certain facility contracts.
Under a companion proposal by Senator Peace, the utilities could issue through the state infrastructure bank an estimated $5 billion in revenue bonds backed by the transition charge.
"They might be non-taxable instruments, we're not sure yet," Takashima said.

The bonds could provide savings to the utilities, and those savings, under Peace's proposal, could be passed on to small business and residential customers in the form of a 10 percent rate reduction, Takashima said.
